questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Egypt is renowned for its rock-cut temples constructed under the orders of Pharaoh Ramses II, and later saved from the rising waters of the Nile due to the Aswan Dam?
questions.context: The temples were relocated in a complex engineering project during the 1960s to prevent submersion.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Italy is famed for its leaning structure caused by unstable foundation soil, originally intended to be a freestanding bell tower for the cathedral of the square?
questions.context: Construction of the tower began in 1173 and took nearly two centuries to complete due to interruptions.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Cambodia is the largest religious monument in the world, originally built as a Hindu temple for the Khmer Empire but gradually transforming into a Buddhist temple by the end of the 12th century?
questions.context: This temple complex is renowned for its grandeur and detailed bas-reliefs.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Peru is an ancient Inca city known for its well-preserved ruins that were rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911 after being lost to the outside world for centuries?
questions.context: Machu Picchu is often mistakenly referred to as the 'Lost City of the Incas'.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in China is renowned for its intricate system of imperial palaces that served as the home of emperors and their households for over 500 years?
questions.context: Located in the heart of Beijing, it is noted for its traditional Chinese palatial architecture.
